Evaluation_Questions: How well did this course, to the extent promised in the syllabus, enable “conversation across lines of difference,” integrate practical and theoretical concerns, or consider and integrate issues of class, gender/sexuality, race/ethnicity, dis/ability, and or global/cultural diversity
Comments_Questions: What was the name of your practicum instructor
What were her/his strengths or weaknesses

Rev. Julie Kelsey and she is phenomenal.

The Rev Kris Lewis-Theerman
Kris

Willis is the best.  He curated such a gentle, fun environment in which to do role-plays without fear or shame.  Our discussions were always rich; his perspective on chaplaincy (in prison and parish) was invaluable.

great listener
exceptionally experienced
very supportive
low stress
I loved our practicum leader! She was incredibly helpful and kind and really guided the group well while pushing us when we needed it.

Willis was a fantastic practicum leader. He was thoughtful and provided really helpful insight during out practicums, and his real life experience was extremely informative when dealing with the things we talked about in class. He also allowed for organic conversation of the things we talked about to occur, and helped guide the practicum in a really helpful way.
He was knowledgeable and encouraged further discussion around what we were interested in talking about. He also has a great sense of humor, which was helpful in dealing with serious role plays.

Kris helpfully brought in her own practical experience to make the class more practical. I thought it could have been more helpful to get more constructive feedback rather than only affirmations after a role play.

We had an excellent small group, and Julie was wonderful in engaging all of us in role play while making us feel completely comfortable in the process. She should definitely continue to lead a small group for this class. She is warm, encouraging and offers deep insights into the material as well as years of pastoral care experience. she is also direct and honest. Between Julie Kelsey and Joyce Mercer, this class is an absolute gem. i loved it!

He had enormous expertise and a personality that wanted to share it with all of us.  His experiences as a prison chaplain and as a church minister were enormously useful.  He is a wise and holy man with much to share, and was always willing to go the extra mile in discussing the scenarios we received from Dr. Mercer and the extensions we posed for him.  He should definitely be invited back next year.

Willis was the greatest. I really appreciated the way he made our practicum group a comfortable environment for each of us to practice and learn through the role plays. He took the time to get to know us and respond to our individual questions and concerns.
Julie brings her own experience as a pastoral care giver.  Positive presence in the room, but not over-bearing.
Strengths: Kris was great! She had an ability to take the scenarios further and make them applicable to our lives and what we could expect in our ministry.

Julie was absolutely amazing. She was incredibly pastoral, which was very helpful when we engaged in the difficult work of the case studies. She allowed us to ask questions as they emerged in the case studies, which I especially appreciated. I am just so grateful that she facilitated my group.

Strengths -
> flexible in allowing students to volunteer for roles, thus allowing us to be aware of and address the areas we felt were necessary
> challenged us to take on roles when necessary
> didn't leave a single role-play as the final answer

Weaknesses -
> lack of experience to reach back to for suggestions or answers in certain scenarios
